intro: Oxytropis roaldii, commonly known as Roald's milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of central Asia. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its sparsely branched stems and small, compound leaves. The plant produces yellow or pale purple flowers in late summer, which are clustered in dense inflorescences. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to harsh, semi-desert environments. Oxytropis roaldii is often found in rocky or sandy habitats and is considered a rare and endemic species in its range.
